The leaders of France, Spain and Portugal on Friday officially approved an ambitious underwater pipeline to bring green hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of Europe

The H2Med project, set to be completed by 2030 at a cost of about ï¿½2.5 billion ($2.6 billion), will help Europe make the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy.

READ MORE
Spain seeks EU cash to link up its 'energy island'
The pipeline between Barcelona and Marseille will carry two million tonnes of hydrogen per year, or 10 per cent of European consumption, once it goes online, said Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez.
ï¿½It is going to be the first major hydrogen corridor in the European Union,ï¿½ Mr Sanchez said.
The pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea will carry green hydrogen, which is made from water via electrolysis in a process using renewable energy.

ï¿½The cost of H2 transmission by pipeline over long distances is 2 to 4 times lower than transmitting electricity over high-voltage lines.ï¿½

Announced at an EU summit in October, the pipeline offers an alternative to the defunct 2003 MidCat pipeline project which was to have carried gas across the Pyrenees from Spain to France.

The leaders of France, Spain and Portugal on Friday officially approved an ambitious underwater pipeline to bring green hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of Europe

The H2Med project, set to be completed by 2030 at a cost of about ï¿½2.5 billion ($2.6 billion), will help Europe make the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy.
It comes as Europe scrambles to reduce its dependence on Russian oil and gas following the invasion of Ukraine.
Following the talks, they released a road map and timeline for completing H2Med which they hope will be partially covered by European funds.

EPA
H2Med aims to boost the decarbonisation of European industry, giving it large-scale access to clean energy from Spain and Portugal, which are hoping to become world leaders in green hydrogen thanks to their numerous wind and solar power farms.
It comes as Europe scrambles to reduce its dependence on Russian oil and gas following the invasion of Ukraine.

EPA
H2Med aims to boost the decarbonisation of European industry, giving it large-scale access to clean energy from Spain and Portugal, which are hoping to become world leaders in green hydrogen thanks to their numerous wind and solar power farms.

The leaders of France, Spain and Portugal on Friday officially approved an ambitious underwater pipeline to bring green hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of Europe

The H2Med project, set to be completed by 2030 at a cost of about ï¿½2.5 billion ($2.6 billion), will help Europe make the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy.

READ MORE
Spain seeks EU cash to link up its 'energy island'
The pipeline between Barcelona and Marseille will carry two million tonnes of hydrogen per year, or 10 per cent of European consumption, once it goes online, said Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez.
ï¿½It is going to be the first major hydrogen corridor in the European Union,ï¿½ Mr Sanchez said.
The pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea will carry green hydrogen, which is made from water via electrolysis in a process using renewable energy.

ï¿½The cost of H2 transmission by pipeline over long distances is 2 to 4 times lower than transmitting electricity over high-voltage lines.ï¿½

Announced at an EU summit in October, the pipeline offers an alternative to the defunct 2003 MidCat pipeline project which was to have carried gas across the Pyrenees from Spain to France.

Initially, the idea was for the pipeline to carry gas from the Iberian Peninsula to central Europe, given Spain and Portugal's huge capacity for turning liquefied natural gas that arrives in tankers back into gas form.
But Mr Costa stressed that the pipeline would carry only green hydrogen.

The leaders of France, Spain and Portugal on Friday officially approved an ambitious underwater pipeline to bring green hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of Europe

The H2Med project, set to be completed by 2030 at a cost of about ï¿½2.5 billion ($2.6 billion), will help Europe make the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy.

READ MORE
Spain seeks EU cash to link up its 'energy island'
The pipeline between Barcelona and Marseille will carry two million tonnes of hydrogen per year, or 10 per cent of European consumption, once it goes online, said Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez.
ï¿½It is going to be the first major hydrogen corridor in the European Union,ï¿½ Mr Sanchez said.
The project will cost around ï¿½2.5 billion, he said at a joint press conference with French President Emmanuel Macron and Portuguese Prime Minister Antonio Costa.
The three leaders formally signed off on the plans in the presence of EU Commission chief Ursula Von der Leyen on the sidelines of a regional EU summit.

The leaders of France, Spain and Portugal on Friday officially approved an ambitious underwater pipeline to bring green hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of Europe

The H2Med project, set to be completed by 2030 at a cost of about ï¿½2.5 billion ($2.6 billion), will help Europe make the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy.
Following the talks, they released a road map and timeline for completing H2Med which they hope will be partially covered by European funds.

The leaders of France, Spain and Portugal on Friday officially approved an ambitious underwater pipeline to bring green hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of Europe

The H2Med project, set to be completed by 2030 at a cost of about ï¿½2.5 billion ($2.6 billion), will help Europe make the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy.

READ MORE
Spain seeks EU cash to link up its 'energy island'
The pipeline between Barcelona and Marseille will carry two million tonnes of hydrogen per year, or 10 per cent of European consumption, once it goes online, said Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez.
The pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea will carry green hydrogen, which is made from water via electrolysis in a process using renewable energy.
But Mr Costa stressed that the pipeline would carry only green hydrogen.
The road map detailed three options for the route of the pipeline, with the preferred one stretching 455km at a maximum depth of 2,600 metres.
Construction will begin in 2025 and last four years and eight months, it said.

The leaders of France, Spain and Portugal on Friday officially approved an ambitious underwater pipeline to bring green hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of Europe

The H2Med project, set to be completed by 2030 at a cost of about ï¿½2.5 billion ($2.6 billion), will help Europe make the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy.
The pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea will carry green hydrogen, which is made from water via electrolysis in a process using renewable energy.

EPA
H2Med aims to boost the decarbonisation of European industry, giving it large-scale access to clean energy from Spain and Portugal, which are hoping to become world leaders in green hydrogen thanks to their numerous wind and solar power farms.
ï¿½The focus of H2 demand is on sectors that are difficult to decarbonise, such as industry and transport,ï¿½ the road map said.

ï¿½The cost of H2 transmission by pipeline over long distances is 2 to 4 times lower than transmitting electricity over high-voltage lines.ï¿½

Announced at an EU summit in October, the pipeline offers an alternative to the defunct 2003 MidCat pipeline project which was to have carried gas across the Pyrenees from Spain to France.

The leaders of France, Spain and Portugal on Friday officially approved an ambitious underwater pipeline to bring green hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of Europe

The H2Med project, set to be completed by 2030 at a cost of about ï¿½2.5 billion ($2.6 billion), will help Europe make the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy.

READ MORE
Spain seeks EU cash to link up its 'energy island'
The pipeline between Barcelona and Marseille will carry two million tonnes of hydrogen per year, or 10 per cent of European consumption, once it goes online, said Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez.

ï¿½The cost of H2 transmission by pipeline over long distances is 2 to 4 times lower than transmitting electricity over high-voltage lines.ï¿½

Announced at an EU summit in October, the pipeline offers an alternative to the defunct 2003 MidCat pipeline project which was to have carried gas across the Pyrenees from Spain to France.

Initially, the idea was for the pipeline to carry gas from the Iberian Peninsula to central Europe, given Spain and Portugal's huge capacity for turning liquefied natural gas that arrives in tankers back into gas form.
It was abandoned in 2019 over profitability issues and objections from Paris and environmentalists.

The leaders of France, Spain and Portugal on Friday officially approved an ambitious underwater pipeline to bring green hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of Europe

The H2Med project, set to be completed by 2030 at a cost of about ï¿½2.5 billion ($2.6 billion), will help Europe make the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy.

The pipeline between Barcelona and Marseille will carry two million tonnes of hydrogen per year, or 10 per cent of European consumption, once it goes online, said Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez.
The pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea will carry green hydrogen, which is made from water via electrolysis in a process using renewable energy.

ï¿½The cost of H2 transmission by pipeline over long distances is 2 to 4 times lower than transmitting electricity over high-voltage lines.ï¿½

Announced at an EU summit in October, the pipeline offers an alternative to the defunct 2003 MidCat pipeline project which was to have carried gas across the Pyrenees from Spain to France.

Initially, the idea was for the pipeline to carry gas from the Iberian Peninsula to central Europe, given Spain and Portugal's huge capacity for turning liquefied natural gas that arrives in tankers back into gas form.

The leaders of France, Spain and Portugal on Friday officially approved an ambitious underwater pipeline to bring green hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of Europe

The H2Med project, set to be completed by 2030 at a cost of about ï¿½2.5 billion ($2.6 billion), will help Europe make the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy.

Spain seeks EU cash to link up its 'energy island'
The pipeline between Barcelona and Marseille will carry two million tonnes of hydrogen per year, or 10 per cent of European consumption, once it goes online, said Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez.
The pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea will carry green hydrogen, which is made from water via electrolysis in a process using renewable energy.
But Mr Costa stressed that the pipeline would carry only green hydrogen.
French President, Emmanuel Macron, left, and Spanish Prime Minister, Pedro Sanchez chat before a joint press conference on the pipeline.

EPA
French President, Emmanuel Macron, left, and Spanish Prime Minister, Pedro Sanchez chat before a joint press conference on the pipeline.

The meeting took place just before a EuroMed 9 summit bringing together Croatia, Cyprus, France, Greece, Italy, Malta, Portugal, Slovenia and Spain

Spain's Mr Sanchez had planned to hold bilateral talks with Italy's new far-right Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, but she pulled out due to illness early on Friday, Rome said.

ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.

Postmedia Network Inc. | 365 Bloor Street East, Toronto, Ontario, M4W 3L4 | 416-383-2300
Article content
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUÂ´s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
She said the EU planned to produce 10 million metric tons of renewable hydrogen by 2030 and to import another 10 million tons.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Unionï¿½s energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

Postmedia Network Inc. | 365 Bloor Street East, Toronto, Ontario, M4W 3L4 | 416-383-2300
Article content
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUÂ´s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

ï¿½We are strengthening European Unionï¿½s strategic autonomy and energy security at a moment when solidarity among Europeans is essential to reduce energy dependency on countries that use energy as a blackmailing tool,ï¿½ Sanchez said, in reference to Russia and the gas crisis that has emerged since the war in Ukraine.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Unionï¿½s energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.
ï¿½Today, the Iberian Peninsula is becoming a major European energy gateway to the world,ï¿½ Von der Leyen said at a joint press briefing.

ï¿½We are strengthening European Unionï¿½s strategic autonomy and energy security at a moment when solidarity among Europeans is essential to reduce energy dependency on countries that use energy as a blackmailing tool,ï¿½ Sanchez said, in reference to Russia and the gas crisis that has emerged since the war in Ukraine.

ALICANTE, Spain (AP) ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Unionï¿½s energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

ALICANTE, Spain -- Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
She said the EU planned to produce 10 million metric tons of renewable hydrogen by 2030 and to import another 10 million tons.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union's energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

ï¿½We are strengthening European Unionï¿½s strategic autonomy and energy security at a moment when solidarity among Europeans is essential to reduce energy dependency on countries that use energy as a blackmailing tool,ï¿½ Sï¿½nchez said, in reference to Russia and the gas crisis that has emerged since the war in Ukraine.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union's energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.
ï¿½Today, the Iberian Peninsula is becoming a major European energy gateway to the world,ï¿½ Von der Leyen said at a joint press briefing.

ï¿½We are strengthening European Unionï¿½s strategic autonomy and energy security at a moment when solidarity among Europeans is essential to reduce energy dependency on countries that use energy as a blackmailing tool,ï¿½ Sï¿½nchez said, in reference to Russia and the gas crisis that has emerged since the war in Ukraine.
ALICANTE, Spain -- Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union's energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

The project will first connect two plants in northern Portugal and northern Spain and then involve a pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea from the northeastern Spanish port of Barcelona to Franceï¿½s Marseille.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
ALICANTE, Spain -- Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
The project is expected to cost 2.5 billion euros ($2.6 billion).
The announcement came after a meeting between Sï¿½nchez, his French and Portuguese counterparts and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in the eastern Spanish city of Alicante.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.
ALICANTE, Spain -- Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.
She said the EU planned to produce 10 million metric tons of renewable hydrogen by 2030 and to import another 10 million tons.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.
ï¿½Hydrogen is a game-changer for Europe,ï¿½ said Von der Leyen.

The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union's energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.
ï¿½Today, the Iberian Peninsula is becoming a major European energy gateway to the world,ï¿½ Von der Leyen said at a joint press briefing.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

The project will first connect two plants in northern Portugal and northern Spain and then involve a pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea from the northeastern Spanish port of Barcelona to Franceï¿½s Marseille.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
She said the EU planned to produce 10 million metric tons of renewable hydrogen by 2030 and to import another 10 million tons.
The H2Mad summit is to discuss a plan for an undersea pipeline that would eventually transport hydrogen and will connect the ports of Barcelona in Spain and Marseille in France.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union's energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

ï¿½We are strengthening European Unionï¿½s strategic autonomy and energy security at a moment when solidarity among Europeans is essential to reduce energy dependency on countries that use energy as a blackmailing tool,ï¿½ Sï¿½nchez said, in reference to Russia and the gas crisis that has emerged since the war in Ukraine.

ALICANTE ï¿½ Spain, France and Portugal agreed Friday to build by 2030 a major undersea pipeline to transport hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to France and eventually the rest of Europe.
The pipeline is aimed at making the European Union's energy supply more independent, a goal expedited by the Russian invasion of Ukraine last February that precipitated an energy crisis.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will ï¿½take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.ï¿½

ï¿½It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen,ï¿½ he added.

The project will first connect two plants in northern Portugal and northern Spain and then involve a pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea from the northeastern Spanish port of Barcelona to Franceï¿½s Marseille.

He said that with the project, they ï¿½aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.ï¿½

Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sï¿½nchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually ï¿½ 10% of the EUï¿½s estimated hydrogen needs.
